Your prior response revolved around the issue of request for 
justification=
 via benefit derived, to warrant effort required to 
understand. The materi=
al supplied was not intended to compel any 
body. 

The GECCO 2007 paper, w=
hile effective at illustrating a new 
capability, was not effective (for me=
) at explaining how the approach 
may be applied to other problems, and whe=
re the current 
implementation boundaries existed. Prior questions unanswer=
ed and 
subsequent reply examples supplied by you proved non-specific beyon=
d 
the flavor contained in the GECCO 2007 paper. This has necessitated 
my =
backing-out the current implementation boundaries. A portion of 
the materi=
als supplied are a sharing of that work product in hopes 
that it may be he=
lpful to others.

I am uncertain, but it appears that your reply presumes t=
hat the flow 
of development of the shared HyperNEAT concept is one-way, wh=
ich 
presently is not the case. I am well aware of the benefit of an 
appro=
priate and timely example. But no teacher, using your example, 
has to conv=
ince his students to expend the effort required to 
understand. It is a pre=
-requisite. Examples follow from demonstrated 
effort at understanding, and=
 are point specific. I merely stated that 
necessity is an effective motiva=
tor.



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Jason G" <jgmath2000@...> wrote:
>
> =
Maybe this is sophomoric, but I can't seem to understand your point 
of vie=
w
> on this.  If everyone believed that the only compelling examples 
are s=
imilar
> to their own problems, then everyone would walk around speaking hi=
s 
or her
> own language. No one would be able to gain common understanding=
, 
which is a
> necessity for progress.  Although it's true that one can on=
ly 
disprove
> things with examples and never fully prove things, anyone wh=
o's 
taught a
> school course, whether it is university or pre-kindergarten=
, 
recognizes the
> benefit of distilling information into it's important c=
omponents.  
This is
> typically done by using an example.
> 
> Ironically =
enough, maybe an example will explain what I mean:  
Let's say
> that the f=
irst papers on HyperNEAT involved using it as a 
discriminator in
> part of=
 a larger system (something which I am currently making good 
progress
> in=
), it becomes harder to both explain the HyperNEAT component of 
the system=

> and to prove how large a part is has played in the overall design.  
Peo=
ple
> who are not familiar with the larger system now have to understand 
t=
he
> entire system in order to fully appreciate HyperNEAT's role in that 
s=
ystem.
> For every person who accepts the result, there's a person who 
arg=
ues either
> that HyperNEAT did not play a large enough role in the larger =

system, or
> that the use of HyperNEAT is somehow limited to this system a=
nd 
other
> systems just like it.
> 
> I think that, in general, the use of=
 geometry in machine learning is
> something that hasn't been exploited unt=
il now.  While people have 
tried to
> work around this by performing some =
spatial preprocessing to the 
input data
> before it enters the learning ag=
ent, no one has developed a 
learning agent
> which inherently possesses th=
is ability.  Now that we have a system 
which
> uses geometry, it becomes i=
mportant for everyone to understand the 
system
> and to baseline their kno=
wledge. There is no easier way to do this 
than to
> show an example which =
anyone can understand and recreate.  
Reproducibility
> is one of the most =
important aspects of research.
> 
> Examples aren't only seen in research. =
 If you look at people who 
submit
> bugs to GCC, they make it a point to e=
xplain the GCC bug using an 
example
> which is 10-15 lines of code, even i=
f the bug something which is 
only found
> in larger projects, like multipl=
e inheritance with templates.  I'm 
sure the
> bug submitter wasn't really =
trying to "solve" multiple inheritance 
with
> templates, as you say, but i=
t was more of a "bump in the road" 
which needed
> to be addressed with a s=
imple example so it could be fixed.
> 
> Similarly, with regards to the exp=
eriment in the GECCO paper, we 
aren't all
> throwing our hats in the air b=
ecause we solved the big-block little-
block
> problem in computer science.=
  What we are doing now is laying down 
the
> foundation so that in the nea=
r future we can say "If you want to 
understand
> how this works, check out=
 the GECCO 2007 paper which has an 
introduction to
> HyperNEAT and an expe=
riment".
> 
> Finally, and this is purely my opinion, writing formalisms an=
d 
closures to
> find out the exact limitations of a system in flux seems l=
ike 
trying to
> catch the wind in a bottle.  The more fruitful exercises i=
nvolve 
debate and
> understanding, two forces which are shifting those lim=
itations 
constantly.
> 
>
